Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Revisiting the Central Dogma at the Genome Scale and in Single Cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1351443
Fan, Rong

The ultimate objective of this research project is to develop a microdevice platform that can enable the measurement of a single cell simultaneously for genomic, transcriptomic, proteomic and phenotypic parameters, in other words, at all the levels of the Central Dogma(DNA to RNA to protein to phenotype). Specifically, the PI will develop a microfluidic device for reliably separating cytoplasmic and nuclear contents from the same single cells followed by whole-pool amplification of genomic DNAs and messenger RNAs. The amplified products will be retrieved and analyzed using state-of-the-art genomics technology to link single-cell genetic variation to the expression of affected genes across the whole genome. Single-cell, multiplex protein assay and quantitative analysis of cellular behaviors (phenotype) can be integrated within this microdevice to further correlate genes, transcripts to the levels of proteins and cellular functions. The PI will apply this platform to investigating stem cell differentiation and potentially provide new insights needed for understanding how gene expression is regulated to determine stem cell fate and diversity. Such analysis is critical to fully addresse a range of fundamental biological questions such as embryonic development, cancer and immune cell diversity.

This project also acts as a backbone for the integration of research and educational activities spanning from K12 through graduate training, from Yale University through the local community. Integrating microtechnology into biology represents an urgent requirement of expertise for the future health science researchers and medical practitioners. The synergy of research and education will result in the development of a virtual micro-physiologic system lab for demonstration to not only Yale College students but also to the general public, and increase the participation of minorities and under-represented groups.

Due to the interdisciplinary nature of the project, this CAREER award by the Biotechnology, Biochemical, and Biomass Engineering Program of the CBET Division is co-funded by the Systems and Synthetic Biology Program of the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes of this NSF CAREER award include the development of three novel microchip technologies for single-cell omics profiling and the deployment of these technologies to improve our understanding of cellular heterogeneity and function in basic and translational biomedical research.

First, we developed a microchip for single-cell protein cytokine secretome profiling, which was applied to the measurement of T-cell activation states and the evaluation of engineered cell therapies. This technology has been commercialized by IsoPlexis and used by 60+ pharmaceutical companies or major hospitals in preclinical and clinical testing of immune cell functions and has generated significant impact in the pharmaceutical and biotechnology industry.

Second, we developed a freeze-thaw microwell-based approach to perform single-cell transcriptome sequencing, which allowed for decoupling of sample procurement and single-cell omics analysis, potentially enabling the wide-spread adoption of single-cell sequencing in distributed testing sites or resource-limited regions/countries. This technology has been licensed for commercialization. We are continuing this research effort to extend this technology to the measurement of multi-omics such as whole pool of microRNAs and mRNAs at the genome scale.

Third, the success of this NSF CAREER project prepared the team to further develop spatially resolved single-cell multi-omics, which is an ongoing project in PI Fan’s laboratory and has attracted significant interest in the fields of developmental biology, immunology, neuroscience, and digital pathology.

Levering the research activities supported by this NSF CAREER award, PI Fan developed an active educational program to promote K-12 training in STEM through summer internship, a summer bootcamp program to teach researchers outside the engineering field the microfabrication techniques through hands-on training to promote the adoption of microengineered tools for systems biology research. This project also supported the training of undergraduate and graduate students to promote their career development in STEM, in particular, in bioanalytical technologies and bioengineering.  PI Fan served on the biotech workforce development advisory committee in the greater New Haven area and contributed significantly to the ecosystem of biotechnology innovation beyond academia.
